title: Have all books and literature available in the world been digitised? - Quora

response.answer_text: Have all books and literature available in the world been digitised? Well, let’s see. I am not at my home, and haven’t been for three years, It will be a few years before I can return home again. That means that I have only a small shelf of books here, not counting my books on weaving (MOST of which are not digitized—call it a dozen or so). And those weaving books are downstairs and I don’t fell like going down, pulling them, carrying them up here,, carrying them back down the stairs, and reshelving them. The Best of Eric Frank Russell. Part of a series of ‘Best of’ SF by authors from the Golden Age pulps. So far as I know, NONE of them have been digitized. I own about 10 of the, most of which are at my home. Psychohistorical Crisis by Donald Kingsbury. Courtship Rite is not available as an ebook, but is as an audio book, so I guess that one is digitized, ditto The Moon Goddess and the Son. And The Devil Will Drag You Under , Jack L. Chalker. Thomas Gray, Philosopher Cat Philip J. Davis. The Martian Named Smith: Critical Perspectives on Robert A. Heinlein’s Stranger In A Strange Land, William H. Patterson Jr. and Andrew Thornton. Language in Thought and Action, S.I. Hayakawa and Alan R. Hayakawa. Pilgrims Through Space and Time, J. O. Bailey. Writers of the 21st Century Series: Robert A. Heinlein, ed. Joseph D. Olander and Martin Harry Greenberg. The Past Through Tomorrow, Robert A. Heinlein. Not digital in the single volume publication, not in the two-volume publication. Science Fiction Handbook, Revised: How to Write and Sell Imaginative Stories, L. Sprague de Camp and Catherine Cook de Camp. The Issue At hand, William Atheling Jr. (James Blish). More Issues At Hand, William Atheling Jr. (James Blish). Heinlein In Dimension, A Critical Analysis, Alexei Panshin. Rite of Passage, Alexei Panshin, audiobook only. To The Queen’s Taste: Elizabethan Feasts and recipes Adapted For Modern Cooking by Lorna J. Sass. To The King’s Taste, Richard II’s Book of Feasts and Recipes Adapted for Modern Cooking, Lorna J. Sass. The Danse Macabre of Women: Ms. fr. 995 of the Bibliotheque Nationale, Ann Tukey Harrison ed. Dragoncharm, Graham Edwards. The Ivory Mirror: The Art of Mortality in Renaissance Europe, Stephen Perkinson and other contributors. Death: A Graveside Companion Will Self and Joanna Ebenstein. Death, Disease, & Famine in Pre-Industrial England, Leslie Clarkson. How I Got To Be Perfect Jean Kerr. The Snake Has All The Lines, Jean Kerr. Too Many Women?: The Sex Ratio Question, Marcia Guttentag and Paul F. Secord. I’m not through the two small shelves of books I have here, but I’m tired of pulling them and now I have to reshelve everything. But I think that answers your question. WTH, here’s one more: The English Dancing Master, or, Plaine and easie Rules for the Dancing of Country Dances, with the Tune to each Dance, John Playford. EDIT: except as noted, NONE of those books have been digitized.

Far from it, but even if they have been, access to them would be problematic because of the complexities of copyright law. You may have heard about Google's digitization project of a bunch of years ago, where they were digitizing all of Harvard's (and a couple other) library collections. That effort was stopped because Google was violating the law--during the process, not even while allowing people to view them. That was easily the largest project ever attempted, and even though Google did A LOT, universities don't collect all kinds of books in the first place. (The most salient example being popular fiction, which is mainly in the purview of public libraries.) These days, I presume all books are *written* digitally, whether by the authors themselves, their assistants, or publishers’ staff, before publication, but not all are commercially released for consumption online. And because the market for older titles, especially non-fiction, is fairly nonexistent, publishers have little motivation to release them, however simple that process must be.
